content.text: **Truth trees** (semantic tableaux) provide a mechanical method for checking validity. Instead of constructing a proof, we try to find a counterexample — and show it's impossible.

content.definition: A tree-structured search for counterexamples. We assume premises true and conclusion false, then systematically decompose formulas. If all branches close (contain contradictions), the argument is valid.

content.text: Each formula type has a decomposition rule. Conjunctions add both conjuncts on the same branch. Disjunctions split into two branches. Negated formulas push the negation inward.

content.title: Tree Decomposition Rules
premises: A ∧ B: Add A and B on same branch
A ∨ B: Split into two branches, one with A, one with B
A → B: Split into ¬A branch and B branch
¬(A ∧ B): Split into ¬A branch and ¬B branch
content.note: Keep decomposing until all formulas are atoms or their negations.

content.definition: A branch containing both P and ¬P for some formula P. A closed branch represents an impossible scenario and is marked ×.

content.text: If all branches close, no counterexample exists — the argument is valid. If any branch stays open (no contradiction), the open branch describes a counterexample — the argument is invalid.
Truth trees are mechanical: just follow the rules. They're especially useful for checking validity quickly without the creativity needed for natural deduction proofs.

content.question: What does a closed branch in a truth tree mean?
options: That scenario is impossible (contains a contradiction)
content.explanation: A closed branch contains P and ¬P — a contradiction. This means that scenario is impossible. If ALL branches close, no counterexample exists and the argument is valid.
